TopicTitle: New Delta-V or charts according to the new aero model (update 1.0)

Articles.Content:
Hi everyone, 

After the new update provided by Squad yesterday (1.0), I started a new career mod with Kerbal Engineer and I'm right now planning to orbit Kerbin with a spaceship. However, I can't find a new Delta-V or charts (like this one [http://deltavmap.com/](http://deltavmap.com/) but updated) for orbiting Kerbin with the new aerodynamics model ![:(](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_sad.gif).

Is it the same as the old one (4500 m/s) or did it changed (like FAR reduced the Delta-V required orbiting in the previous version) ![:confused:](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_huh.gif) ?

Thx in advance (I count on you guys, don't let me down )

***BY THE WAY, I'M NEW HERE, SO PLEASE IF IT IS IN THE WRONG SUBFORUM, LET ME KNOW AND TELL ME WHERE I SHOULD POST***

I know that it is significantly changed. FAR (a mod) used to have some Delta-V charts that are apparently fairly close. I'll see if I can find one.

Edit: based on a quick search, it appears that Delta-V between planets should remain the same (which kind of makes sense when I, you know, actually *think* about it ![:rolleyes:](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_rolleyes.gif)). Where it *will* change is on bodies with an atmosphere.

That being said, I'm sure that there will be plenty of new material being produced by the community in the coming days/weeks/months. My brief experience is that the new aero works kind of like FAR, but I also never have used FAR/NEAR.

Oh, and WELCOME!

Research

some experiments by GoSlash27 show that the Delta V for kerbin orbit hangs around 3400-3500. link to thead: [http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/116993-Helpful-1-0-observations](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/116993-Helpful-1-0-observations)

Go give him some rep
I've been hearing 3,300 m/s thrown around for LKO, Not sure how much it varies right now though.

Anything above 3000m/s for getting to LKO is too much. It can be done for less than 3000m/s, but that takes a bit of forethought. The efficiency of the launch is highly dependent on flight profile and initial TWR, but with a bit of practice anybody should be able to do it for 3000m/s routinely.
